questions.question: Question 1: What is the false statement regarding carcinoma larynx?

options.a: Squamous cell is the most common histological type
options.b: Glottis is the most common site
options.d: Tobacco is an important causative factor

questions.explanation: Laryngeal carcinoma is more common in males. Laryngeal cancer • Male:Female ratio is 10:1 • Risk factors: Smoking tobacco and alcohol • 90-95% are squamous • Most common site: Glottis followed by supraglottis and subglottis.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following cancers presents with hoarseness of voice as its earliest symptom?
questions.explanation:
Glottic carcinoma presents with hoarseness of voice as its earliest symptom. Lesions of the vocal 
cords affect its vibratory capacity. Therefore they are diagnosed early and have a better prognosis. Supraglottic and subglottic growths are often silent. Hoarseness is a late symptom.

questions.question:
Question 3: Which of the following is not the reason behind the development of hoarseness of voice in 
laryngeal carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Phonotrauma is not the reason behind the development of hoarseness of voice in laryngeal 
carcinoma. It occurs due to overuse of voice and is associated with the development of benign 
lesions such as vocal nodules and cysts. Hoarseness in supraglottic cancer and subglottic cancer indicates spread of disease to: • Vocal cords with infiltration of the thyroarytenoid muscle • Involvement of recurrent laryngeal nerve • Cricoarytenoid joint involvement. Hoarseness in glottic carcinoma is early because lesions of the cord affect its vibratory capacity.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 60-year-old man is diagnosed with carcinoma limited to the glottis of the larynx. Which of 
the following lymph nodes would be initially involved?
questions.explanation:
Tumours limited to the glottis usually do not spread to any lymph node station as there are no 
lymphatics in the vocal cords. However, if the tumour invades the supra- or the infra- glottic spaces, lymph node spread can 
occur. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common malignant tumour of the larynx. Glottis is the most 
common site of cancer. 560 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following laryngeal carcinomas has maximum lymph node involvement?

options.d: All have equal chances of lymph node involvement

questions.explanation:
Supraglottic carcinoma has the highest chance of lymphatic spread in the larynx. Lymph node enlargement is often a presenting complaint as it occurs early in the course of the 
disease.

questions.question:
Question 6: A patient has been diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma limited to the supraglottis. Which of 
the following subsites will not be affected?
questions.explanation:
The Pyriform sinus is not a subsite of the supraglottis. Epiglottis, false cords, aryepiglottic folds (medial wall of the pyriform sinus), and arytenoids are 
the subsites of supraglottis. Aryepiglottic folds are shared between the supraglottis and hypopharynx.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 55-year-old man is diagnosed with supraglottic carcinoma. Which of the following lymph 
node levels is the earliest to be involved?
questions.explanation:
Level II (upper jugular) and III (middle jugular) lymph nodes are the most common and earliest 
nodes involved in supraglottic carcinoma.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following statements is false regarding supraglottic carcinoma?

options.a: Epiglottis, false vocal cords are most commonly involved
options.b: Lymphatic spread to upper and middle jugular lymph nodes
options.c: Hoarseness of voice is an early symptom
options.d: Bilateral nodes seen in epiglottic cancer

questions.explanation:
Hoarseness of voice is a late symptom of supraglottic carcinoma. The most common site of supraglottic carcinoma is the epiglottis followed by false cords and then 
aryepiglottic folds. Nodal metastases occur early to the upper and middle jugular lymph 
nodes. Bilateral metastases can be seen in cases of epiglottic cancer. Supraglottic growths are 
often silent as hoarseness is a late symptom.

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient has been posted for a surgical procedure to excise cancerous lesions from the vocal 
cords. Which laser is most commonly used?
questions.explanation:
Endoscopic resection with CO2 laser is most commonly used in laryngeal surgeries. Carcinoma of the mobile membranous vocal cords can be precisely excised with the CO2 laser 
under the microscope. It gives the same result as being traditionally treated with 
radiotherapy. Laser excision has the advantage of lower cost, lower duration of treatment, and 
morbidity. 561 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: A 50-year-old man presents to you with complaints of weight loss, hoarseness of voice, and 
difficulty in breathing. On direct laryngoscopy, a mass involving both the vocal cords with 
extension to the subglottis is seen. Cords are immobile and there is no lymph node 
involvement. A biopsy confirms the diagnosis of glottic carcinoma. What is the next step in 
the management of this case?
questions.explanation:
The clinical picture of glottic carcinoma involving immobile vocal cords with extension to the 
subglottis suggests that the tumour belongs to the T3 stage. The treatment of choice is concurrent 
chemotherapy and radiotherapy. TNM classification of glottic carcinoma (American Joint Committee on Cancer, 2002) Treatment of laryngeal cancers: TLM: Transoral laser microsurgery; RT: Radiotherapy; OPL: Open partial laryngectomy; CT:

questions.question:
Question 11: In which of the following conditions would you not recommend a total laryngectomy as the 
treatment?

options.a: Glottic carcinoma with invasion of the thyroid cartilage
options.b: Glottic carcinoma involving the posterior commissure
options.c: Transglottic tumours with fixation of the vocal cords
options.d: Tumour involving both vocal cords with normal mobility

questions.explanation:
Tumour limited to both vocal cords with normal mobility can be classified as stage T1b. Treatment 
will include radiotherapy or transoral laser microsurgery. There is no indication for a total 
laryngectomy. Total laryngectomy is indicated in: • All T4 lesions • Invasion of thyroid or cricoid cartilage • Bilateral arytenoid cartilage involvement • Lesions of the posterior commissure • Failure after radiotherapy or conservation surgery • Transglottic cancers with cord fixation. It is contraindicated in patients with distant metastasis. Treatment of T3 cancers is controversial, open vertical hemilaryngectomy and more 
extensive partial laryngectomies are used in carefully selected cases. Total laryngectomy or CRT is 
recommended for bulky T3 tumors or tumors not suitable for conservation laryngeal surgery.

questions.question:
Question 12: In the oncology ward, four patients have been diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma. Which of 
the following patients would you advise for transoral laser microsurgery as the first choice?

options.a: A patient with vocal cord palsy, with subglottic extension
options.b: A patient with tumor limited to one cord, with normal mobility
options.c: A patient with tumor invading the thyroid cartilage
options.d: A patient with tumor limited to larynx, with fixed cord

questions.explanation:
Among the given options, a patient with tumor limited to one cord, with normal mobility will be 
advised for transoral laser microsurgery as the first choice. TNM staging in this patient is T1a. Option A: TNM staging here is T2b and the patient is advised for chemoradiotherapy as the first 
choice. Option C: TNM staging here is T4a and the patient is advised for total laryngectomy as the first 
choice. Option D: TNM staging here is T3 and the patient is advised for chemoradiotherapy as the first 
choice. TNM classification of glottic carcinoma (American Joint Committee on Cancer, 2002) Treatment of laryngeal cancers: TLM: Transoral laser microsurgery; RT: Radiotherapy; OPL: Open partial laryngectomy; CT:

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is an indication of high tracheostomy?
questions.explanation:
Laryngeal carcinoma is an indication of high tracheostomy. It is done at the level of the 1st 
tracheal ring and an opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland. 564 
Sold by @itachibot The disadvantage of a high tracheostomy is subglottic stenosis at the level of the cricoid and 
perichondritis of the cricoid. However, in laryngeal carcinoma this would be a temporary measure 
as the definitive management is total laryngectomy. Tracheostomy involves making an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the 
trachea. Functions: • Provides an alternative pathway for breathing by bypassing the obstruction. • Improves alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space by 30-50% and reducing airway resistance • Uses a cuff to protect the airways from secretions and blood • Allows suction of secretions in the setting of the impaired cough reflex. • Allows positive pressure respiration • Allows administration of anesthesia Indications: • Respiratory obstruction due to • Infections (laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis, epiglottitis) • Trauma due to external injury, mandibular or maxillofacial fractures • Neoplasms • Foreign bodies or edema • Bilateral abductor paralysis • Congenital anomalies • Retained secretions • Inability to cough due to coma, spasm, or paralysis of respiratory muscles • Aspiration of pharyngeal secretions • Painful cough • Respiratory insufficiency due to emphysema, chronic bronchitis 565 
Sold by @itachibot Instruments
